passages.text: TAkoDgA8gIAkA8eaakAgkw8gIA0A8Dk8mDNAm:8ge8pA8kenA80ACAtrA8kle0ga5mm8Dt8x7y%w8WIDRI8 Dk8AkDn5gAl8ge8pA8Dt8gIA805tsA8ea8E v- )|HS)|8pt8q|fb1U8bRjef8stimate pegs FY26 GST collection at INR 11.8 trn, a \(10.9\%\) yoy increase. Even without GST rationalization, there is a risk for GST and other tax collection to be lower in FY26, as nominal GDP growth is expected to moderate to \(9.0\%\) yoy vs. \(10.1\%\) yoy assumed as per Budget estimates. The FY26 Union budget has estimated GST compensation cess of INR1.67 trn, a \(9.2\%\) yoy jump over FY25 revised estimate of INR1.53 trn. Net proceeds in GST compensation fund after servicing of loans and interest are estimated around INR500 bn. If \(50\%\) of this can be used to offset the likely shortfall in GST revenue, then the fiscal deficit slippage risk would come down to INR200- 250 bn or just \(0.1\%\) of GDP. Sovereign ratings upgrade, future fiscal uncertainty and debt sustainability

When we last undertook a debt sustainability exercise about a year back (see, "Analyzing India's debt sustainability and ratings upgrade prospects", 18 Aug 2024), WA8RetRmrIA8gl5gD5BWDMm8mDNAm:8sAg85805gDtsk8rds05gDk8t argument was that based on "adequate debt repayment capacity" parameter, and given the macro improvement over the last several years, EtIDB8oEp5pm:8lAkA0CAk8 58gWeHtegrl805gDtsk8ros05hAthis backdrop, the decision by S&P Global Ratings to announce a sovereign ratings upgrade to BBB from BBB- for India on \(14^{\text{th}}\) August 2025 (after a gap of 18 long years), hardly comes us a surprise, at least to us.

x5kg8ae0W50l8ge8gIDk8aDkR5m8: A50w80DkNk8ge8oWeWgl85tl8RetkAMrAtgm:8aDkR5m8l5CA8 DtR0A5kA8ue to tariff threat posed by the new US administration, a lower- than- expected nominal GDP growth profile and revenue uncertainty due to GST rates rationalisation. Also, in the coming years, the centre's fiscal will have to accommodate higher expenditure outlay (INR 2- 2.5 trn) related to \(8^{\text{th}}\) Pay Commission awards, which can flatten the debt- consolidation path, if nominal GDP growth remains subdued, thereby pushing fiscal deficit higher.

Keeping these factors in mind, WA80ACDkDg8er08lApg8krkg5Dt5pDmDg:8AuA0RDkA8ae08gIA8 EtID5t8AReten:8Dt8gIDk8koARD5m80A0r9rtain whether India's forecasted debt consolidation path has changed materially from the findings of our last exercise. This assumes particular importance, as Government of India's medium- term fiscal roadmap is now aimed towards achieving a sustained debt consolidation path by the end of this decade, but without pre- committing explicitly to any fiscal deficit target.

Our analysis reveals that, despite GST rates rationalisation, increased outlay on account of \(8^{\text{th}}\) day Commission awards and no significant fiscal deficit consolidation from current levels (we assume consolidated general budget deficit sustaining around current levels of \(7.3\%\) of GDP), Dg8Dk8eekkDprfAB8g8meWA08Dgk8 lApgicT.8g8s,5fbU8ea8cT.8p:8x71b8qDt8gIA8A50mDA08Th'8AuA0RDkAw8er08ae0AR5kg8W5k8 kmDsI8m:8meWA085g8,- fFU8eabovide8 nominal GDP growth averages around \(10.5 - 11\%\) during the forecasting period. In our view, barring some unforeseen shocks, a \(10.5 - 11\%\) nominal GDP growth assumption is realistic based on an average \(6.0 - 6.5\%\) real GDP growth and \(4 - 4.5\%\) inflation (in terms of GDP deflator) over the forecasting period. Our forecast is similar to IMF's estimate, which sees India's public sector debt/GDP moderating to \(75.9\%\) by 2031 (see "Staff Report for the 2024 Article IV Consultation for India", Feb 2025), but is slightly higher compared to RBI's forecast of \(73.4\%\) over the same forecasting horizon (see, "The Shape of Growth Compatible Fiscal Consolidation", Feb 2024).

28Eno5Rg8et8aDkRmisdfy of Finance officials have assured that GST 2.0 will be fiscally sustainable, with higher consumption expected to offset any shortfall in revenues. Also, once the compensation cess ends this year and GST rate increases from 28% to 40% on "sin" and luxury goods, that 12% increase will be an additional revenue for both the Centre and the states. That may help offset the revenue loss because of the rate rationalization. The compensation cess will lapse by the end of this year and cannot be levied thereafter. It had earlier been expected to remain in force until March 2026, primarily on products in the 28% bracket such as automobiles and tobacco. The cess, which was initially expected to end in 2022, had been extended to enable the Centre to repay Covid-era borrowings taken to compensate states for revenue shortfalls.

TAkoDgA8gIAkA8eaakAgkw8gIA0A8Dk8mDNAm:8ge8pA8kenA80ACAtrA8kle0ga5mm8Dt8x7y%w8WIDRI8 Dk8AkgDn5gAl8ge8pA8Dt8gIA805tsA8ea8E v- )HS))8pt8q)fb1U8b8dJgof8stimate pegs FY26 GST collection at INR 11.8 trn, a 10.9%yoy increase. Even without GST rationalization, there is a risk for GST and other tax collection to be lower in FY26, as nominal GDP growth is expected to moderate to 9.0%yoy vs. 10.1%yoy assumed as per Budget estimates. If a part of compensation cess can be used to fund the likely shortfall in GST tax revenue, say 50%, then the risk of fiscal slippage will reduce even further. The FY26 Union budget has estimated GST compensation cess of INR1.67 trn, a 9.2%yoy jump over FY25 revised estimate of INR1.53 trn. Net proceeds in GST compensation fund after servicing of loans and interest are estimated around INR500 bn. If 50% of this can be used to offset the likely shortfall in GST revenue, then the fiscal deficit slippage risk would come down to INR200- 250 bn or just 0.1% of GDP. 28 Aug&AtA05gDet&chB0Aae0nk&ge8rertgA08h&g50D&h&g10A&l5gdal25% tariff announced by the US administration on Indian exports took effect on 27 August. With this, the total levy on Indian exports to the US currently stands at \(50\%\) . While we still think that eventually the tariffs will come down post negotiations, the next few months could see a dampening impact on India's exports to the US. To counter the downside impact on growth and to continue with the theme of accelerating reforms, Government of India recently announced its decision to cut GST rates from the current tax slabs (5%, 12%, 18%, and 28%) to a simplified two- slab structure of \(5\%\) and \(18\%\) . Under the proposed structure, nearly \(90\%\) of taxable items currently in the \(28\%\) bracket would shift to the \(18\%\) slab. Almost \(99\%\) of goods in the \(12\%\) bracket would move down to \(5\%\) . Only 5- 7 products, considered as "singoods" and high- end luxury cars would attract a special \(40\%\) rate.

28OenoekDgDet&ea&chB8RemmA&gDet&tifcurrent data of GST returns as available with Goods and Service Tax Network, the average GST rate for 2023- 24 was \(11.64\%\) . After rates rationalization, the average is likely to fall slightly below \(10\%\) . This compares with an average rate of about \(14.5\%\) when GST was first implemented in 2017. About \(70 - 75\%\) of GST revenues collected in FY24 came from the \(18\%\) slab, \(5 - 6\%\) came from the \(12\%\) bracket, \(6 - 8\%\) from the \(5\%\) slab, while the highest tax slab of \(28\%\) contributed \(13 - 15\%\) to the revenues.

Also, once the compensation cess ends this year and GST rate increases from 28% to 40% on "sin" and luxury goods, that 12% increase will be an additional revenue for both the Centre and the states. That may help offset the revenue loss because of the rate rationalization. The compensation cess will lapse by the end of this year and cannot be levied thereafter. It had earlier been expected to remain in force until March 2026, primarily on products in the 28% bracket such as automobiles and tobacco. The cess, which was initially expected to end in 2022, had been extended to enable the Centre to repay Covid-era borrowings taken to compensate states for revenue shortfalls.

The Covid- 19 pandemic in 2020 had a severe impact on the deficit and debt dynamics of almost all countries in the world, though in varying degrees. India was also severely impacted, with general government deficit and debt rising sharply in the immediate aftermath of the pandemic, which was unavoidable. For example, in FY19, when the reported fiscal deficit was \(3.4\%\) of GDP, the EBR in that fiscal year was \(0.9\%\) of GDP; therefore, incorporating the EBR would have resulted in fiscal deficit rising to \(4.3\%\) of GDP. In FY17 and FY18, the reported fiscal deficit was \(3.5\%\) of GDP, but adding \(0.5\%\) of GDP of EBR for both those years, the augmented fiscal deficit of the central government stood at \(4.0\%\) of GDP. Post FY22, the central government has taken all expenditure on balance sheet and the practice of providing off-balance sheet EBR has stopped, in a bid to promote fiscal transparency. We assume that, in the coming years, the centre's fiscal deficit will not fall below \(4.50\%\) of GDP, which would be 50bps higher than the pre-pandemic low of \(4.0\%\) of GDP (after adding \(0.50\%\) of GDP worth EBR to the headline fiscal deficit of \(3.5\%\) of GDP). Assuming the states' fiscal deficit stabilizes at \(2.8\%\) of GDP, this will likely result in general government deficit stabilizing at the current \(7.3\%\) of GDP within the forecast horizon. In the rest of this report, we use our own economic forecasts to present a debt sustainability analysis of the general government, to ascertain the medium- term debt/GDP trajectory under various scenarios.

Real GDP grows around \(6.0 - 6.5\%\) average in the rest of this decade (till FY31); nominal GDP growth averages about \(10.5 - 11\%\) during the forecasting period; With a flexible inflation targeting framework firmly in place, CPI inflation averages in the \(4.0 - 4.5\%\) range for the rest of this decade; we have assumed GDP deflator (mix of CPI and WPI) to average \(4.5\%\) in the years ahead; Real interest rate on public debt works out to \(2.5\%\) on an average (derived from \(7.0\%\) nominal rate and \(4.5\%\) GDP deflator- based inflation); We assume general government deficit (centre + state) to trough at \(7.3\%\) of GDP through the forecasting period, with the centre's fiscal deficit stabilizing around \(4.5\%\) of GDP, and \(2.8\%\) of GDP in case of states. There is scope for general government deficit to be lowered further beyond this, but we have assumed for now that, given the need for supporting growth through fiscal impulse and accommodating \(8^{\text{th}}\) Pay Commission recommended higher wages in the coming years, the combined deficit may not fall below the current \(7.3\%\) of GDP mark (pre- Covid 10- year average was \(6.9\%\) of GDP). Primary deficit eases in the period ahead, averaging close to \(2.2\%\) of GDP; primary spending rises by \(5 - 6\%\) in real terms, while revenues rise \(10.5 - 11\%\) on an average in nominal terms, in line with the projected nominal GDP growth for the rest of this decade. The rupee remains broadly stable against the USD, with a slightly depreciation bias in the medium term; note that, given India's relatively small public external debt burden, the exchange rate assumption matters little in the debt sustainability exercise.

A few years prior to the Covid- 19 pandemic in 2020, the central government had formed an expert committee in 2016 to recommend a desirable fiscal and debt consolidation path for India over the medium term. The xDkR5m8vAkoetkDpDmDg:85tl8 'rlsAg8 P5t5sAnAtg8 'Rg8 qxv'P/ review committee submitted its recommendations before the announcement of the Union Budget on 1st February 2017, with the detailed report being released subsequently in mid- April.

BIA8xv'P8RennDggAA80ARennAtIAI8gIA8RAtg05m8seCA0tnAtg8RetgDtrAk8et8glA8 o5gl8ea8aDkR5m8RetkemD|lgDcthe medium- term goal of bringing the centre's fiscal deficit down to \(2.5\%\) of GDP by FY23 (from \(3.5\%\) of GDP in FY18), which would result in the centre's debt/GDP coming down to \(40\%\) of GDP (from about \(49\%\) in FY18). The committee also recommended a desirable fiscal path for the state governments, so that cumulatively the debt/GDP of states can remain constant at around \(20\%\) of GDP throughout the forecasting period. This would require state fiscal deficit to reduce from \(3.0\%\) of GDP in FY17 - by about \(1\%\) of GDP - to \(2.0\%\) by FY23. If this was achieved, then India's overall public debt/GDP ratio would have moderated to about \(60\%\) of GDP by FY23, a \(10\%\) drop from FY18 levels (general government deficit was close to \(70\%\) of GDP in FY18).

Earlier such risks arose mainly from banking sector NPAs which had deteriorated significantly in the last decade. However, the public sector banks' balance sheets have been cleaned up and the NPAs have fallen below \(3\%\) , a record low. Now the risk of contingent liabilities arises mostly from state finances. As per RBI data, overall state guarantees amounted to about \(3.7\%\) of GDP by FY21. While the centre has stopped the practice of providing off- balance sheet resources (Extra Budgetary resources or EBR) and now everything is accounted as on- balance sheet expenditure, a similar accounting treatment by states at a later point of time could increase deficit and debt, a non- trivial risk, in our view. Recall that in past years, even before the Covid- 19 crisis, a decision to accommodate the interest

burden of the UDAY scheme as an on-balance sheet expenditure item along with the costs of farm loan waivers given by certain states deteriorated the health of the states' fiscal balances materially, a risk which exists even today, given the guarantees that exist in the form of contingent liabilities.

As our exercise shows, public debt/GDP is likely to be on a sustained downtrend due to positive growth- interest differential and there is little risk associated with the funding of the public debt as bulk of the debt is in domestic currency. Foreign currency denominated debt is small - less than \(5\%\) of GDP - and even within that more than half of it is owed to multilateral institutions. India's total external debt stood at USD 736.3 bn by the end of FY25, while India's total FX reserves currently stand at USD 695 bn. Ratio of short- term debt to total debt is relatively low at \(18.3\%\) and ratio of FX reserves to total debt stood at 90.8% by the end of FY25. India's macro outlook - both short- and medium- term - remains bright, with likelihood of sustained strong growth outperformance amidst anchored inflation, positive real rates, continued fiscal consolidation, healthy external and domestic financial sector and expected macro dividend from ongoing supply- side reforms. As our exercise shows, public debt/GDP is likely to be on a sustained downtrend due to positive growth- interest differential and there is little risk associated with the funding of the public debt as bulk of the debt is in domestic currency.

Our analysis reveals that, despite GST rates rationalisation, increased outlay on account of \(8^{\text{th}}\) Pay Commission awards and no significant fiscal deficit consolidation from current levels (we assume consolidated general budget deficit sustaining around current levels of \(7.3\%\) of GDP), Dg8Dk8oekkDprfABrB8meWA08Dgk8 IApgicT.8ge8,SfbU8ea8cT.8p:8x71b8qDt8gIA8A50mDA08Th8AuA0RDkAw8er08ae0AR5kg8W5k8 kmDslgm:8meWA085g8,- fFU8eabovide8 nominal GDP growth averages around \(10.5 - 11\%\) during the forecasting period. In our view, barring some unforeseen shocks, a \(10.5 - 11\%\) nominal GDP growth assumption is realistic based on an average \(6.0 - 6.5\%\) real GDP growth and \(4 - 4.5\%\) inflation (in terms of GDP deflator) over the forecasting period.

Our forecast is similar to IMF's estimate, which sees India's public sector debt/GDP moderating to \(75.9\%\) by 2031 (see "Staff Report for the 2024 Article IV Consultation for India"), Feb 2025), but is slightly higher compared to RBI's forecast of \(73.4\%\) over the same forecasting horizon (see, "The Shape of Growth Compatible Fiscal Consolidation", Feb 2024).

Macroeconomic fluctuations often account for most of the risks associated with exposures to instruments that promise to pay fixed or variable interest rates. For an investor who is long fixed- rate instruments (thus receiving these cash flows), increases in interest rates naturally lift the discount factors applied to the expected cash flows and thus cause a loss. The longer the maturity of a certain cash flow and the higher the move in the discount factor, the higher will be the loss. Upside surprises in inflation, fiscal funding needs, and FX depreciation rates are among the most common adverse macroeconomic shocks to receivers. But counterparty exposure, issuer creditworthiness, client segmentation, regulation (including changes in assets holding limits for different types of investors), changes in tax policies, currency convertibility (which may constrain currency conversion, repatriation of profits and/or liquidation of positions), and settlement issues related to local clearing houses are also important risk factors. The sensitivity of fixed- income instruments to macroeconomic shocks may be mitigated by indexing the contracted cash flows to inflation, to FX depreciation, or to specified interest rates - these are common in emerging markets. The index fixings may - by construction - lag or mis- measure the actual move in the underlying variables they are intended to track. The choice of the proper fixing (or metric) is particularly important in swaps markets, where floating coupon rates (i.e., coupons indexed to a typically short- dated interest rate reference index) are exchanged for fixed coupons. Funding in a currency that differs from the currency in which coupons are denominated carries FX risk. Options on swaps (swaptions) the risks typical to options in addition to the risks related to rates movements.
